prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6: 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), H30alpha, continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is Science Goal #1
Observations of N113 HII region in Band 6: 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), H30alpha, continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Because we observe 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously, the tolerance of the setting is very limited as shown in knowledgebase on Science Portal. We set the parameters so that the OT doesn't issue any errors or warnings. The velocity bandwidth of 153 km/s is needed to cover the wide spectra of strong outflows from the luminous YSOs. H30alpha and SiO(5-4) lines are expected to have much wider line widths than CO lines, and we set the bandwidth of 1875 MHz with a velocity resolution of 2.5 km/s for H30alpha and 1.56 km/s for SiO(5-4). The choice of the bandwidth, 1875 MHz, is to increase the continuum sensitivity.

An angular resolution of 0.8" (0.19 pc) is definitely needed to detect outflows and resolve dense cores whose size is smaller than 1 pc. We request the ACA because we expect to have extended 12CO and 13CO emission up to 20" in size.

We assume the typical temperature of 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) of ~10K toward cold clouds, and C18O(2-1) of a few K toward high density regions. We expect the linewidth of CO lines are 1-5km/s. We then set our sensitivity to 0.65K at a velocity resolution of 0.3km/s which is reasonable for investigating the dynamical structure of molecular clouds. This is almost the same sensitivity of our Cycle 1 N159 observations. The typical continuum flux of a few mJy, and the current 0.1mJy is good enough to detect the emission. H30alpha is also detected with the past observations whose sensitivity is similar. The detection of SiO(5-4) is a bit uncertain, but we expect to have strong emission in regions with strong shocks.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3: 13CO(1-0), C18O(1-0), CS(2-1), H40alpha, continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is Science Goal #2
Observations of N113 HII region in Band 3: 13CO(1-0), C18O(1-0), CS(2-1), H40alpha, continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The bandwidth of 160 km/s is wide enough to cover the specra. We set velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s to precisely investigate the dynamics of the molecular gas. H40alpha is expected to have much wider line width than CO lines, and we set the bandwidth of 1875 MHz with a velocity resolution of 3.4 km/s. The choice of the bandwidth, 1875MHz, is to increase the continuum sensitivity.

Although the higher spatial resolution will be achieved at Band 6, we need at least 1.5" to resolve the molecular clouds structure especially of dense cores. We expect the 13CO emission up to 20" thus we do not request the ACA time.

We assume the typical temperature of 13CO(1-0) of ~10K toward cold clouds, C18O(1-0) and CS of a 2-5K toward high density regions. We expect the linewidth of CO lines are 1-5km/s. We then set our sensitivity to 0.65K at a velocity resolution of 0.3km/s which is reasonable for investigating the dynamical structure of molecular clouds. This is almost the same sensitivity of our Cycle 1 N159 observations. The typical continuum flux of a few mJy, and the current 0.07 mJy is good enough to detect the emission. H40alpha is also detected with the past observations whose sensitivity is similar.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3: HCO+(1-0), HCN(1-0), H13CO+(1-0), H13CN(1-0), CS(2-1), H40alpha, continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is Science Goal #3
Observations of N113 HII region in Band 3: HCO+(1-0), HCN(1-0), H13CO+(1-0), H13CN(1-0), CS(2-1), H40alpha, continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The bandwidth of 200 km/s is wide enough to cover the specra. We set velocity resolution of 0.2km/s to precisely investigate the dynamics of the molecular gas. H40alpha is expected to have much wider line width than CO lines, and we set the bandwidth of 1875 MHz with a velocity resolution of 5.8 km/s. The choice of the bandwidth, 1875MHz is to increase the continuum sensitivity.

Although the higher spatial resolution will be achieved at Band 6, we need at least 1.5" to resolve the molecular clouds structure especially of dense cores. The lines in this SG are the high-density tracers, and the distribution is expected to be compact. We expect the largest angular structure of ~15", and thus we don't need the ACA.

We assume the typical temperature of these molecular lines of a few K toward high density regions. We expect the linewidth of these lines are 1-5 km/s. We then set our sensitivity to 0.45K at a velocity resolution of 0.3km/s which is reasonable for investigating the dynamical structure of molecular clouds. H40alpha is also detected with the past observations whose sensitivity is similar. The typical continuum flux of a few mJy, and the current 0.05 mJy is good enough to detect the emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6: H13CO+(3-2), H13CN(3-2), SiO(6-5), CS(5-4), continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is Science Goal #4
Observations of N113 HII region in Band 6: H13CO+(3-2), H13CN(3-2), SiO(6-5), CS(5-4), continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The bandwidth of 130 km/s is wide enough to cover the spectra. We set velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s to precisely investigate the dynamics of the molecular gas.

An angular resolution of 0.8" (0.19pc) is definitely needed to resolve dense cores whose size is smaller than 1pc. The lines in this SG are the high-density tracers, and the distribution is expected to be compact. We expect the largest angular structure of ~12", and thus we don't need the ACA.

We assume the typical temperature of these molecular lines of a few K toward high density regions. We expect the linewidth of these lines are 1-5km/s. We then set our sensitivity to 0.45K at a velocity resolution of 0.3km/s which is reasonable for investigating the dynamical structure of molecular clouds. The detection of SiO(6-5) is a bit uncertain, but we expect to have strong emission in regions with strong shocks. The typical continuum flux of a few mJy, and the current 0.2 mJy is good enough to detect the emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to image one of the most prominent star formation regions in the Large Magellanic Cloud N 113 at a 0.2 pc resolution with ALMA in the molecular transitions that probe a wide density range (10^2-10^7 cm^-3) to study both the dense clumps/cores and the lower density gas in the interclump regions. ALMA is the only instrument that can provide high enough angular resolution to resolve the clumps and their embedded cores in the LMC. A combination of the 12CO(2-1), 13CO(1-0) and (2-1), C18O(1-0) and (2-1), CS(2-1) and (5-4), HCO+(1-0), HCN(1-0), H13CO+(1-0) and (3-2), H13CN(1-0) and (3-2), SiO(6-5) lines will allow us to investigate physical conditions and kinematics of the molecular gas at great detail, and detect outflows. We will also probe the physical properties and dynamics of the ionized gas using the H30a and H40a radio recombination lines and dust with 1 mm and 3 mm continuum. By combining the proposed ALMA data with a wealth of multiwavelngth data already available for N 113, we will build a comprehensive picture of the interstellar medium gas phases and dust within N 113 to study the initial conditions for massive star formation in a low-metallicity environment.
